text: so I started working in the claimant
institute in 2008 as a marketer with an
expertise in brand management and what
they said was we want to see how far
knowledge travels and what that means in
the traditional academic unit is we want
a communication specialist that will
translate what research is so other
people understand it and what I came to
understand my real value was in seeing
the value of research in understanding
how a lay person might use research and
to move themselves into action so for
five years I was working on this and
developing products and ways of us
integrating marketing into research and
I'll say I've become a little bilingual
I do understand what you mean when you
say theoretical framework and I would
argue my colleagues at the claimant and
de stute have become bilingual and they
start to question things around the
value of research but in 2013 ebay asked
me to do a keynote presentation at their
women's initiative network to talk about
this and I said oh I don't do that
that's what they do and they said no we
want you to help people see what to do
we understand that bias exists we just
don't know what to do about it so i'm
going to show you an exercise i
developed from them in language based on
a research study that i read which was
about at rice university they studied
how letters of recommendation with
communal or agentic language affected
the outcome and whether those candidates
were perceived as good candidates for
leadership so what I do is I ask people
my audience to describe a top performer
just to describe them with a few words
and I say Tom performer top performer
top performer many times I say do a
thought experiment with me imagine I
recruited that top performer away and
you have to pick a substitute and this
would never happen just imagine these
two descriptions are the summaries of
those two candidates and it is a thought
experiment so I know they're written
really do
we just go with me pick one and in the
audience's traditionally they'll pick
80% description be now when they're
really smart of course they'll wait to
see in the Noma gender former general

balanced now we're starting to do other
written experiments and then revealing
the results that we can show to the
difference now this talk has actually
become really helpful for us I've given
it over 10,000 times and a number of
camp are to 10,000 people in a number of
companies but of course working agenda
Research Institute they pushed me and
they say well does this really create
change or are people just now seeing
bias so our framework is what we call
see bias block bias so the first half is
what I just did was help people see bias
and then we had to come with other ways
to help them block bias and so we talk
about our research projects that kind of
underpin what this dynamic does the
first one we worked with an Internet
company shelly corral presented this
work last time and we went through their
performance reviews and what we came up
with was a review of the kinds of
languages that are used to describe what
we might call a woman's brand and a
man's brand at companies so this was our
seed bias project we really are defining
the ways that we can start to understand
how men are women are described
differently and valued differently but
when we go to the teams and say what
would you like to do to fix this like
well you can't just switch the language
right you have to do something else so
that's phase two of our project which is
not see bias but what we would call our
block bias interventions where we're
asking teams to co-design solutions with
us to block bias and while they've used
the tool of language to see how it works
in their workplace they do not use
language as a tool to them block bias
will give them a suite of options to
choose what would you like to do to fix
bias in your team the number one
solution they tend to pick is what they
call their criteria checklist now there
are two dimensions of this that are
really important one is that they
actually define criteria of performance
before they evaluate people the second
is in a conversation they align around
the meaning of both I guess you would
call then turn
in the external narrative of these words
and as a result we found that language
helps you see what bias how it plays out
in your workplace but to get at the
internal narrative we've developed tools
that help them understand how to use
criteria in order to block bias
